title.value: E3Bind: An End-to-End Equivariant Network for Protein-Ligand Docking
title.justification: The title is taken directly from the first mention of the paper's title in the text.
title.quote: E3BIND: AN END-TO-END EQUIVARIANT NETWORK FOR PROTEIN-LIGAND DOCKING

extractions.description: This research paper introduces E3Bind, an end-to-end equivariant network designed for predicting the docking pose of ligands to protein targets. Unlike traditional methods and some recent deep learning models, E3Bind iteratively refines the ligand pose with special attention to geometric constraints. The model demonstrates enhanced performance over other methods with experiments on standard benchmark datasets.

type.justification: The paper focuses on the development and experimental evaluation of the E3Bind model, comparing its performance with other existing methods.
type.quote: Experiments on standard benchmark datasets demonstrate the superior performance of our end-to-end trainable model compared to traditional and recently-proposed deep learning methods.

name.justification: The paper deals with protein-ligand docking, which is a common task in computational biology, specifically in drug discovery and bioinformatics.
name.quote: In silico prediction of the ligand binding pose to a given protein target is a crucial but challenging task in drug discovery.

name.justification: The paper uses computational techniques for biological data, fitting well within the sub-research field of bioinformatics.
name.quote: In silico prediction of the ligand binding pose to a given protein target is a crucial but challenging task in drug discovery.

name.justification: The focus on predicting protein-ligand interactions directly relates to drug discovery.
name.quote: This work focuses on flexible blind self-docking, where we aim to predict the positions, orientations and conformations of docked molecules.

name.justification: The paper specifically introduces and evaluates this model.
name.quote: we propose E3Bind, an end-to-end equivariant network that iteratively updates the ligand pose.

is_contributed.justification: E3Bind is introduced and detailed within this paper.
is_contributed.quote: we propose E3Bind, an end-to-end equivariant network that iteratively updates the ligand pose.

is_executed.justification: The model is empirically evaluated in the paper via experiments and comparison to other methods.
is_executed.quote: Empirical experiments show that E3Bind is competitive against state-of-the-art blind docking methods.

is_compared.justification: The model's performance is compared against several other methods including traditional and recent deep learning approaches.
is_compared.quote: Experiments on standard benchmark datasets demonstrate the superior performance of our end-to-end trainable model compared to traditional and recently-proposed deep learning methods.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The E3Bind model is a contribution of this paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: we propose E3Bind, an end-to-end equivariant network that iteratively updates the ligand pose.

name.justification: TankBind is mentioned as a comparison model in this paper.
name.quote: Distinct from the above methods, TankBind (Lu et al., 2022) drops the burden of conformation sampling by predicting the protein-ligand distance map, then converting the distance map to a docked pose using gradient descent.

is_contributed.justification: TankBind is referenced as an existing model from other works.
is_contributed.quote: Distinct from the above methods, TankBind (Lu et al., 2022) drops the burden of conformation sampling by predicting the protein-ligand distance map, then converting the distance map to a docked pose using gradient descent.

is_executed.justification: The paper compares the performance of E3Bind to TankBind, indicating that both models were executed for empirical comparison.
is_executed.quote: Distinct from the above methods, TankBind (Lu et al., 2022) drops the burden of conformation sampling by predicting the protein-ligand distance map, then converting the distance map to a docked pose using gradient descent.

is_compared.justification: TankBind is one of the models to which E3Bind's performance is compared.
is_compared.quote: Our model achieves state-of-the-art on most metrics. Specifically, E3Bind shows exceptional power in finding ligand poses with high resolution, where the percentage of predicted poses with RMSD < 2 Å increases by 33% compared to the previous state-of-the-art DL-based model TankBind.

referenced_paper_title.value: TankBind: Trigonometry-Aware Neural Networks for Drug-Protein Binding Structure Prediction
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper title for TankBind is cited along with the year and authors.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Distinct from the above methods, TankBind (Lu et al., 2022) drops the burden of conformation sampling by predicting the protein-ligand distance map, then converting the distance map to a docked pose using gradient descent.

name.justification: EquiBind is another comparison model mentioned in this paper.
name.quote: Recently, Stärk et al. (2022) proposed EquiBind, an equivariant model that directly predicts the coordinates of the docked pose.

is_contributed.justification: EquiBind is referenced as an existing model from other works.
is_contributed.quote: Recently, Stärk et al. (2022) proposed EquiBind, an equivariant model that directly predicts the coordinates of the docked pose.

is_executed.justification: The paper compares the performance of E3Bind to EquiBind, indicating that both models were executed for empirical comparison.
is_executed.quote: E3Bind achieves 2.1 Å for the 25-th percentile of the ligand RMSD, ourperforming all previous methods by a large margin.

is_compared.justification: EquiBind is one of the models to which E3Bind's performance is compared.
is_compared.quote: Recently, Stärk et al. (2022) proposed EquiBind, an equivariant model that directly predicts the coordinates of the docked pose.

name.justification: The paper explicitly mentions using the PDBbind v2020 dataset for training and evaluation.
name.quote: We use the PDBbind v2020 dataset (Liu et al., 2017) for training and evaluation.

name.justification: The paper references the CSAR 2011 Benchmarking Exercise in the context of comparing their results.
name.quote: Numbers for score-based methods are taken from the EquiBind paper (Stärk et al., 2022). *The GLIDE only uses a single thread since the multi-threaded version requires a separate license.

referenced_paper_title.value: Lessons Learned in Empirical Scoring with Smina from the CSAR 2011 Benchmarking Exercise

referenced_paper_title.quote: Lessons learned in empirical scoring with smina from the csar 2011 benchmarking exercise.

name.justification: TorchDrug was used to calculate the ligand node features.
name.quote: The ligand node features {hli }1≤i≤nl are calculated by a TorchDrug (Zhu et al., 2022) implementation of the graph isomorphism network (GIN) (Xu et al., 2018).

referenced_paper_title.value: Torchdrug: A Powerful and Flexible Machine Learning Platform for Drug Discovery
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper title for TorchDrug is cited along with the year and authors.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The ligand node features {hli }1≤i≤nl are calculated by a TorchDrug (Zhu et al., 2022) implementation of the graph isomorphism network (GIN) (Xu et al., 2018).

name.justification: RDKit was used to obtain the unbound ligand structure.
name.quote: In the flexible blind self-docking setting, the docked ligand conformation needs to be inferred besides its position and orientation. The model is thus provided with an unbound ligand structure, which could be obtained by running the ETKDG algorithm (Riniker & Landrum, 2015) with RDKit (Landrum et al., 2013).

referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper title for RDKit is cited along with the year and authors.
